bibl.title: Orders from F.H. Beach to the Quartermaster of the Columbia Barracks, February 21, 1902

div1.p: Beach reports that government vehicles may not be used for private purposes, i.e. entertainment.

div1.head: Orders from F.H. Beach to the Quartermaster of the Columbia Barracks, February 21, 1902
div1.opener:
FROM GEN. J. R. KEAN
HEADQUARTERS COLUMBIA BARRACKS.
Columbia Barracks, Cuba,
February 21st, 1902.
To the
QUARTERMASTER,
Columbia Barracks, Cuba.
Sir:
div1.p:
I am directed by the Commanding Officer to inform you that
no transportation will be furnished to the Pavilion for hops or other
forms of entertainment unless by special authority in each case, to
those officers of the Department Staff, who hold quarters in this
post and are provided with vehicles and drivers by the government.

You are hereby charged with the execution of this order and
will report all violations of the same.

A copy of this has been furnished each officer above referred
to.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully, (Sgd) F. H. Beach,
Captain, 7th Cavalry,
Acting Adjutant. L.S. 74,C.B.C.'02.
Official copy respectfully furnished Major J.R. Kean, Surgeon,
U. S. Army, Superintendent Department of Charities.
T.A. Baldwin
Colonel, 7th Cavalry,
Commanding.
